title: 112_hr3189
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teaching Children to Save Lives Act of 2011". Congress finds that heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States, with sudden cardiac arrest being the leading cause of death in young athletes. Sudden cardiac arrest kills an estimated 5,000 to 7,000 children and young people per year. The American Heart Association estimates that 40,000 lives could be saved annually through the chain of survival, which includes prompt emergency notification, CPR, defibrillation, and advanced cardiac life support. Only 36 states have laws encouraging CPR or automated external defibrillator use. Encouraging CPR and AED training in schools can significantly increase survival rates for sudden cardiac arrest. Teaching students these life-saving skills, along with healthy behaviors, can save lives and improve emergency response in schools. Encouraging CPR and AED training in schools can increase survival rates for sudden cardiac arrest, choking, and stroke by improving emergency response skills. Grants for CPR training in public schools are available. The Secretary of Education can award grants to local educational agencies or targeted schools for CPR and AED training courses. Funds can be used for training, materials, manikins, AED devices, and other equipment as approved by the Secretary. Eligibility requires submission of an application to the Secretary. The Secretary awards grants for CPR and AED training programs to local agencies or targeted schools. Eligibility requires demonstrating implementation of AED training in conjunction with CPR training. Grants are prioritized based on need for initiating or supporting training programs in schools or communities. The Secretary awards grants for CPR and AED training programs to local agencies or targeted schools based on demonstrated need for support or expansion of existing programs. Partnerships with community organizations are encouraged to aid in providing training, and a report to Congress is required within 1 year of funds being appropriated. The Secretary awards grants for CPR and AED training programs to local agencies or targeted schools. A report to Congress is required to detail grant amounts, recipients, fund usage, and impact on program development in schools. Definitions for "targeted school" and "local educational agency" are provided. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2017.
